summary: This is a transcript of a DOJ Office of the Inspector General interview with Federal Bureau of Prisons Lieutenant T. , conducted on March 16, 2022, as part of an investigation into the death of inmate Jeffrey Epstein. The interview focuses on camera system failures at MCC New York around August 8-10, 2019, a phone call allegedly made by Epstein on August 9, and procedures related to the emergency response on August 10.

events.title: Camera System Failure Discovered
events.description: Lieutenant T.  discovers the NiceVision camera system at MCC New York is not recording and many cameras are blacked out/offline while reviewing footage to locate an inmate. She reports it to Captain  and communications technician I. .

events.title: Epstein's Alleged Phone Call
events.description: According to hearsay relayed by Lieutenant , Unit Manager Bullock gave Jeffrey Epstein a phone call, reportedly to his mother, on the evening of August 9, 2019. A call log for a ~21 minute call starting at 6:58 PM is discussed.

events.title: Epstein Found Deceased
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein is found deceased in his cell in the Special Housing Unit (SHU) at MCC New York. Correctional Officers Tova Noel and Michael Thomas discover him and activate the body alarm.

events.title: OIG Interview of Lieutenant
events.description: The DOJ Office of the Inspector General conducts a voluntary, sworn interview with Federal Bureau of Prisons Lieutenant T.  as part of its investigation into the death of Jeffrey Epstein.

keyFacts: The camera system at MCC New York failed on August 8, 2019, with many cameras blacked out/offline and none recording, impairing the ability to retrieve video footage.
Lieutenant  wrote a memorandum about the camera failure on August 10, 2019, but there is a discrepancy between her recollection and Captain 's about when he was notified of the problem.
Hearsay indicates Unit Manager Bullock gave Jeffrey Epstein a phone call on the evening of August 9, 2019, which the witness states was against policy as it was unmonitored and unrecorded.
The interview reveals standard BOP policy requires all inmate phone calls to be recorded and monitored, with special procedures for non-ITS calls, which the witness was unaware of.
Procedures for emergency body alarm responses are detailed, including that all available staff should respond and that control center logbooks should record the event.
